> It talks about the "Uncanny Valley", the threshold at which
> simulated human eyes and faces become creepy-looking because
> they're in the space between looking cartoonish and actually
> looking real enough to pass for human:

Roger Ebert mentioned that in a review of some movie - Final Fantasy 
I think.

> The article suggests going back in the other direction--making
> avatars less human, more stylized, more cartoonish.  But for those
> who want to forge ahead, and actually try to capture realism, this
> might be a very interesting experimental domain.

You'd pretty much have to have interaction with humans for the 
fitness function, right?  I doubt there's any fully automated way of 
closing that final 1%.  But, maybe NPCs in games with rich 3D 
environments or the avatar on an online help system could get 
feedback from the user regarding how much the character gives them 
the willies.
